Transition Prefab¶

Transitions modify the position, rotation, scale, and color of child objects when the attachment turns on and off. The Transition prefab is a simple game object that contains the Transition component.

Using the Transition Prefab¶

 1. Drag a Transition prefab to an Attachment game object on a HandAttachments prefab. 2. Select the parent Attachment game object in the hierarchy panel so that you can see the AttachmentController component in the Unity Inspector. Then drag your Transition game object to the Transition slot of the AttachmentController. 3. Add the desired child game objects and components as children of the Transition object. 4. Set the transition properties:

  1. Enable the “Animate...” checkboxes for the properties that you want to animate during the transition.

  2. Set the Simulate slider to 0.

  3. Adjust the “on” properties to the values you want when the attched objects are fully on.

  4. Set the Simulate slider to -1.

  5. Adjust the “off” properties to the values you want when the attched objects are fully off.

  6. Adjust the easing curves, if desired. The part of the curve from -1 to 0 is used when transitioning from off to on; the part of the curve from 0 to +1 is used when transitioning from on to off.

    Note: you can move the Simulate slider back and forth to observe the transition in action.

    Note: the “on” color of a child object is taken from its material. This color is blended with the Transition Color using the Unity Color.Lerp() function.

  1. Add code to call the AttachmentController Activate() and Deactivate() functions. These functions initiate the transitions. You can use detectors to call these functions. For example, for an Arm HUD, you could use a combination of ExtendedFingerDetector and the PalmDirectionDetector to turn on the attachment whenever the open hand faced the camera.

Key Components¶

The key components in the Hand Attachments prefab include:

Transition (Script)¶

A transition operates on a Unity transform to animate position, rotation, and scale. Any child objects to be animated must be children of the transition’s root transform. Color can be animated when supported by the shaders used in the materials of the child objects. Color changes are applied directly to any child objects.

Each animation type has an easing curve defined by a Unity AnimationCurve property. The domain of this curve is -1 to +1, with 0 being the fully on point along the curve. When a transition is played, the portion of the curve from -1 to 0 is used during the transition from off to on and the portion from 0 to +1 is used for the transition from on to off. The range of the curve is 0 to 1. At 0, the “on” property is fully in effect; at 1, the “off” property is fully in effect.

You can view the current transition is the editor by using the Simulate slider. When the slider is set to 0, the transition is shown in the fully on state; when the slider is -1 or +1, the transition is shown in its fully off state.

  • Root Transform – the transform that is animated.
  • Animate Position – enables animation of position.
  • On Position – the position of the root transform when the attachment is in its on state.
  • Off Position – the position of the root transform when the attachment is in its off state.
  • Position Curve – the easing curve for the position animation.
  • Animate Rotation – enables animation of rotation.
  • On Rotation – the rotation of the root transform when the attachment is in its on state.
  • Off Rotation – the rotation of the root transform when the attachment is in its off state.
  • Rotation Curve – the easing curve for the rotation animation.
  • Animate Scale – enables animation of scale.
  • On Scale – the scale of the root transform when the attachment is in its on state.
  • Off Scale – the scale of the root transform when the attachment is in its off state.
  • Scale Curve – the easing curve for the scale animation.
  • Animate Color – enables animation of color.
  • Color Shader Property Name – the name of the shader property controlling color.
  • Transition Color – the color of the child objects when the attachment is in its off state. (Child objects retain their original colors when the attachment is in its on state.)
  • Color Curve – the easing curve for the position animation.
  • Duration – the time it takes to animate the transition in seconds.
  • Simulate – updates the transition in the editor.
  • On Start event – dispatched when a trasition begins.
  • On Animation Step event – dispatched at each update. You can use this event to drive more complex animations.
  • On Complete event – dispatched when a transitions ends.
